Executive Summary - Halbert Trust #2H

Devon Energy, owner and operator of the Halbert Trust #2H, has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes.  Devon's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release. 
Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Natural gas (methane) and associated condensate (pentane) is collected from the surrounding field and where the condensate is separated and sent to eventually be sold for domestic consumption. This gas contains impurities and must be brought into specification before residue companies will purchase this gas. 

General Accident Release Prevention and Program Information

Halbert Trust #2H is regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) risk management program (RMP).  Halbert Trust #2H is not considered to be a PSM facility.  Halbert Trust #2H is classified as a "normally unoccupied remote facility" as per the definition found in 29 CFR 1910.119(b) and thus is not applicable to PSM requirements according to 29 CFR 1910.119(a)(2)(iii).  However, should this status change, Halbert Trust #2H must be re-evaluated for PSM applicability.      

Devon Energy, encourages employees to participate in safety and accident prevention.  Employees have access to facility accident prevention program.  

Devon Energy, keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.  These documents will be located at the Carthage field office and address chemical properties and associated hazards.  

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/ex

posure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs).  Halbert Trust #2H also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing maintenance activities.

Devon Energy, has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the process are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.  

Halbert Trust #2H maintains written procedures that address various modes of operations.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  These procedures are periodically reviewed.  

Devon personnel are properly trained according to the facility operating procedures for process operations. Halbert Trust #2H has implemented a training program for all employees involved in operating a process.  New employees receive basic training in facility operations.  Refresher training is conducted on an as needed basis.  All of this training is documented for each operator.

Halbert Trust #2H uses contractors for maintenance and repair purposes.  Devon Energy, evaluates contractor safety programs and performance indicators. All maintenance will be conducted by contracted maintenance companies who are knowledgeable about maintaining the equipment.  Procedures will follow manufacture's, vendors or trade association guidelines.  Contract Maintenance Companies will be responsible for making sure that their workers are trained in the maintenance of equipment items. 

All maintenance personnel should be aware that the equipment may contain flammable hydrocarbons, high pressure gasses & liquids; hot surfaces may be present and there may be other haz

ards at the site.  All personnel must review MSDS sheets if they are not familiar with the substances at the site.  Be sure to contact a Devon representative and ask them about these and all other hazards that may be at this site. 

All inspections and testing will be carried out using established Devon procedures.  Please contact Devon representatives concerning the latest Devon inspection and Testing requirements.

All records concerning maintenance will be kept on file by a Devon representative.

Devon Energy, investigates incidents that result in, or reasonably could result in, a fire/explosion, release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to facility management for resolution.

Chemical - Specific Prevention Steps

The processes at the Halbert Trust #2H have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The following is a description of existing safety features applicable to the prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility.  

Universal Prevention Activities

The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all RMP-covered processes at the Halbert Trust #2H.  Collectively, these prevention program activities prevent or mitigate potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

Specialized Safety Features

The Halbert Trust #2H has safety features on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release.  The following types of safety features are used in the covered process:

Release Detection

1.	Tanks are gauged
2.	Tanks/vessels are equipped with level and pressure sensors
3.	Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms and shutdowns
4.	High/Low alarms and shutdowns

Release Containment/Control

1.	Berms

around tanks
2.	Process relief valves venting vapors to the atmosphere to prevent vessels from rupturing
3.	Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases
4.	Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual and automated)
5.	Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high temperature)
6.	Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system)

Release Mitigation

1.	Trained emergency response personnel
2.	Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing)
3.	SPCC Plan
4.	Fire extinguishers

Emergency Response Program Information

The Halbert Trust #2H maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to the release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  In addition, the facility has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes.  Periodic drills or tabletop exercises are conducted to test the response plan.

The overall emergency response program for the Halbert Trust #2H is coordinated with the San Augustine County Local Emergency

Planning Committee (LEPC). The Hon. Randy Williams is the contact for the LEPC (936/275-2762).  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  The Halbert Trust #2H has around-the-clock communications capability.  Devon Energy operators are automatically called in the event of a process upset.  The operator will then call the appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department).  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, the Devon Energy conducts periodic emergency drills that involve emergency response organizations, and the Halbert Trust #2H provides annual refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the facility.  

Five - Year Accident History

The Halbert Trust #2H is currently being built as of June 11, 2011.  According to Devon personnel, no accidents have occurred.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

According to Devon personnel, a PHA will not be conducted because Halbert Trust 2H is not a PSM facility.  Devon Energy, owner and operator of the Halbert Trust #2H, has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes.  Devon's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.
